docs.lead_paragraph: The 2016 election will be about ideologies, not individuals, despite much media attention to the latter.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column argues that despite excessive media attention, personalities of candidates in the 2016 presidential race are relatively unimportant; contends that what truly matters is enormous ideological gulf between the two parties; examines outlook for nation under a Republican and Democratic president.
docs.snippet: The 2016 election will be about ideologies, not individuals, despite much media attention to the latter.

docs.lead_paragraph: Li Xiaohe has set herself up for the long haul in a cramped but sunny room in western Beijing, about a block from China's most renowned cancer hospital. Her laundry dries on hangers and her husband cooks in a communal kitchen as she embarks on an 84-day program of chemotherapy, following the removal of part of her right breast.

headline.main: Cancer Surge in China Prompts Rise of Special Patient Hotels
headline.print_headline: Cancer Surge in China Prompts Rise of Special Patient Hotels

docs.lead_paragraph: Underappreciated stocks in health care and Japan — an industry and a nation in transition — provided gains for three funds in the first quarter.

headline.main: Three Ways to Beat a Benchmark
headline.print_headline: Three Ways to Beat a Benchmark

docs.abstract: Examination of how three managed funds beat Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in first quarter of 2015; strategies undertaken by Tocqueville Opportunity, Blackrock Mid-Cap Growth Equity and T Rowe Price Japan outlined.
docs.snippet: Underappreciated stocks in health care and Japan — an industry and a nation in transition — provided gains for three funds in the first quarter.

docs.lead_paragraph: There will be no federal loans, work-study money or grants to finance students’ annual $28,000 tuition, which includes housing in gender-segregated dorms.

headline.main: To Keep Free of Federal Reins, Wyoming Catholic College Rejects Student Aid
headline.print_headline: To Keep Free of Federal Reins, Wyoming Catholic College Refuses Aid

docs.abstract: Wyoming Catholic College in Lander, Wyo, is among handful of religious colleges that have refused federal aid due to concerns over federal rules on birth control and same-sex marriage; move represents expensive bid to run school according to Catholic ideals and without fear of government interference.
docs.snippet: There will be no federal loans, work-study money or grants to finance students’ annual $28,000 tuition, which includes housing in gender-segregated dorms.

docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor, a lawyer and two professors discuss a calculation.

headline.main: Disability and Health Care: Calculating How Much a Life Is Worth
headline.print_headline: Calculating How Much a Life Is Worth

docs.snippet: A doctor, a lawyer and two professors discuss a calculation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The latest salvo in a four-year battle with Teladoc, a national company that provides telephone or video consultations with doctors.

headline.main: Texas Medical Panel Votes to Limit Telemedicine Practices in State
headline.print_headline: Texas Medical Panel Votes to Limit Telemedicine Practices in State

docs.abstract: Texas Medical Board, which licenses and regulates physicians in state, votes to sharply restrict use of telemedicine; is latest move in four-year battle with Dallas-based Teladoc, which provides telephone or video consultations with staff doctors for routine medical problems; while many states are supporting such services in effort to increase access to medical care under Affordable Care Act, Texas has moved in opposite direction.
docs.snippet: The latest salvo in a four-year battle with Teladoc, a national company that provides telephone or video consultations with doctors.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A perspective that was once characterized by comfort and optimism has increasingly been overlaid with stress and anxiety.

headline.main: Middle Class, but Feeling Economically Insecure
headline.print_headline: Middle Class, or So They Think

docs.abstract: Growing body of research shows that middle-class Americans increasingly feel vulnerable, indication of degree to which idea of belonging to middle class has shifted from one of optimism and comfort to one of uncertainty and stress; many in middle class say they fear economic uncertainty, feeling that is justified by both stagnating incomes and loss of jobs as well as widening income gaps (Series: A Shifting Middle).
docs.snippet: A perspective that was once characterized by comfort and optimism has increasingly been overlaid with stress and anxiety.

docs.lead_paragraph: An appeals court ruled Friday that Missouri can't limit health insurance navigators' ability to help people obtain insurance under President Barack Obama's health care law — a ruling that advocates say could have implications for other states that have instituted similar restrictions.

headline.main: Missouri Health Care Navigator Law Pre-empted, Court Rules
headline.print_headline: Missouri Health Care Navigator Law Pre-empted, Court Rules
